2.verse: as the prophet Isaiah wrote: “[Look; Behold,] I ·will send [am sending] my messenger ahead of you, who will prepare your way [Mal. 3:1].”

10.verse: Immediately, as Jesus was coming up out of the water, he saw ·heaven [the sky] ·open [split open]. The ·Holy Spirit [Spirit] ·came down [descended] on him like a dove [either in the form of a dove, or in bird-like descent],

12.verse: ·Then [Immediately] the Spirit ·sent [drove; compelled] Jesus into the ·desert [wilderness].

16.verse: Jesus Chooses His First Followers - When Jesus was walking by ·Lake Galilee [the Sea of Galilee], he saw Simon [Peter; cf. 3:16] and his brother Andrew ·throwing [casting] a net into the lake because they were fishermen.

17.verse: Jesus said to them, “Come ·follow me [be my disciples], and I will ·make you [teach you how to] fish for people.”

18.verse: So Simon and Andrew immediately left their nets and followed him.

19.verse: Going a little farther, Jesus saw two more brothers, ·James and John, the sons of Zebedee [James the son of Zebedee, and his brother John]. They were in a boat, ·mending [preparing] their nets.

21.verse: Jesus Forces Out an Evil Spirit - Jesus and his ·followers [disciples] went to Capernaum [a town on the northwest shore of Lake Galilee; it became Jesus’ home base]. On the Sabbath day he went to the synagogue and began to teach.

23.verse: Just then, a man was there in the synagogue who had an ·evil [defiling; unclean] spirit in him. [Demons were viewed as “unclean” or defiling spirit-beings.] He shouted,

24.verse: “Jesus ·of Nazareth [the Nazarene]! ·What do you want with us? [Let us alone!; What business do we have with each other? What to us and to you?] Did you come to destroy us? I know who you are—God’s Holy One!”

28.verse: And the ·news [report; fame] about Jesus spread quickly everywhere in the area of Galilee.

29.verse: Jesus Heals Many People - As soon as Jesus and his ·followers [disciples] left the synagogue, they went to the home of Simon [Peter; 3:16] and Andrew, together with James and John.

30.verse: Simon’s mother-in-law was sick in bed with a fever, and ·the people [they; either the people or the disciples] told Jesus about her.

31.verse: So Jesus went to her bed, took her hand, and ·helped [raised] her up. The fever left her, and she began ·serving them [waiting on them; presumably meal preparation].

32.verse: That evening, after the sun went down, the people brought to Jesus all who were sick and ·had demons in them [were demon-possessed].

34.verse: Jesus healed many who had different kinds of sicknesses, and he ·forced many demons to leave people [drove/cast out many demons]. But he would not allow the demons to speak, because they knew who he was. [They knew he was the Messiah; Jesus wanted to avoid premature publicity.]

35.verse: [Very] Early the next morning, while it was still dark, Jesus ·woke [got up] and left the house. He went to a ·lonely [isolated; deserted] place, where he prayed.

38.verse: Jesus answered, “·We should [Let us] go to other towns around here so I can preach there too. That is the reason I came.”

40.verse: Jesus Heals a Sick Man - A man with ·a skin disease [leprosy; the term does not refer to modern leprosy (Hansen’s disease), but to various skin disorders; Lev. 14] came to Jesus. He fell to his knees and begged Jesus, “You can ·heal me [make me clean; leprosy rendered a person ceremonially defiled (“unclean”), and so unable to participate in Israel’s religious life] if you ·will [are willing; want to].”

44.verse: “Don’t tell anyone about this. But go and show yourself to the priest. And offer the ·gift [offering; sacrifices] Moses commanded for ·people who are made well [your cleansing; Lev. 14:1–32]. This will ·show the people [be a public testimony to; be evidence for] what I have done.”

As a result, Jesus could not enter a town ·if people saw him [publicly]. He stayed in ·places where nobody lived [secluded/deserted places], but people ·came [kept coming] to him from everywhere.

1.verse: Jesus Heals a Paralyzed Man - A few days later, when Jesus came back to Capernaum, the news spread that he was at home.

6.verse: Some of the ·teachers of the law [scribes] were sitting there, thinking to themselves,

7.verse: “Why does this man ·say things like that [speak this way]? He is ·speaking as if he were God [blaspheming]. ·Only God can forgive sins.” [“Who can forgive sins but God alone?”; cf. Is. 43:25].

13.verse: Jesus Calls Levi to Follow Him - Jesus went to the lake again. The whole crowd ·followed him [came to him] there, and he taught them.

14.verse: While he was walking along, he saw a man named Levi son of Alphaeus sitting in the tax collector’s booth [probably a tariff booth for taxing goods in transit]. Jesus said to him, “Follow me,” and he stood up and followed Jesus.

15.verse: Later, as Jesus was ·having dinner [reclining; around a low table, the posture for a formal banquet or dinner party] at Levi’s house, many tax collectors and sinners were eating there with Jesus and his followers. Many people like this followed Jesus.

16.verse: When the ·teachers of the law [scribes] who were Pharisees saw Jesus eating with the tax collectors and sinners, they asked his followers, “Why does he eat with tax collectors and sinners?” [Tax collectors were despised because they worked for the Roman rulers and were notorious for corruption and extortion.]

17.verse: Jesus heard this and said to them, “It is not the healthy people who need a doctor, but the sick. I did not come to ·invite [call] ·good people [the righteous; meaning the “self-righteous” who feel no need to repent] but to ·invite [call] sinners [those who recognize their need to repent].”

19.verse: Jesus answered, “The ·friends of the bridegroom [or wedding guests; children of the wedding hall] do not fast while the bridegroom is still with them [Jesus is referring to himself; John 3:29; Rev. 19:7]. As long as the bridegroom is with them, they cannot fast.

20.verse: But the ·time [days] will come when the bridegroom will be taken from them, and ·then [in that day] they will fast.

21.verse: “No one sews a patch of unshrunk cloth over a hole in an old ·coat [garment]. Otherwise, the patch will shrink and pull away—the new patch will pull away from the old ·coat [garment]. Then the ·hole [tear] will be worse.

22.verse: Also, no one ever pours new wine into old ·leather bags [wineskins]. Otherwise, the new wine will break the ·bags [skins; as the wine ferments and expands], and the wine will be ·ruined [lost] along with the ·bags [skins]. But new wine should be put into new ·leather bags [wineskins].”

24.verse: The Pharisees said to Jesus, “Why are your followers doing what is not lawful on the Sabbath day?” [Gleaning was viewed as work, and therefore forbidden on the Sabbath; Ex. 34:21.]

25.verse: Jesus answered, “Have you never read what David did when he and ·those with him [his companions] were hungry and needed food [1 Sam. 21:1–6]?

26.verse: ·During the time of Abiathar [or, In the account about Abiathar] the high priest, David went into God’s house and ate the ·holy bread [consecrated bread; bread of presentation], which is lawful only for priests to eat [Ex. 25:30; Lev. 24:5–9]. 1.verse: Jesus Heals a Man’s Hand - Another time when Jesus went into a synagogue, a man with a ·crippled [paralyzed; deformed; shriveled] hand was there.

2.verse: ·Some people [They; probably the Pharisees; see 2:24, 27] watched Jesus closely to see if he would heal the man on the Sabbath day so they could accuse him.

14.verse: Jesus ·chose [appointed] twelve [paralleling the twelve tribes of Israel] and called them apostles [“apostle” means a messenger, or someone sent with a commission]. He wanted them to be with him, and he wanted to send them out to preach

18.verse: Andrew, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James the son of Alphaeus, Thaddaeus, Simon the Zealot [either religiously zealous, or a (former) member of the revolutionary movement known as Zealots],

22.verse: But the ·teachers of the law [scribes] from Jerusalem were saying, “·Beelzebul [another name for Satan] is ·living inside [possessing] him! He uses power from the ·ruler [prince] of demons to ·force [drive; cast] demons out of people.”

25.verse: and a ·family [household; house] that is divided cannot ·continue [stand].

26.verse: And if Satan ·is [rises; rebels] against himself and ·fights against his own people [is divided], he cannot ·continue [stand]; that is the end of Satan.

27.verse: No one can enter a strong man’s house and ·steal [seize; plunder] his things unless he first ·ties up [binds] the strong man [Is. 49:24–25]. Then he can ·steal [seize; plunder] things from the house. [Satan is the strong man and his possessions are the people Jesus is freeing from Satan’s power.]

29.verse: But anyone who ·speaks against [blasphemes] the Holy Spirit will never be forgiven; he is guilty of ·a sin that continues forever [a sin with eternal consequences; an eternal sin].”

31.verse: Jesus’ True Family - Then Jesus’ mother and ·brothers [or brothers and sisters; the Greek word can mean “siblings”; cf. 6:3] arrived. Standing outside, they sent someone in to tell him to come out.

32.verse: Many people were sitting around Jesus, and they said to him, “Your mother and brothers are ·waiting [looking; asking] for you outside.”

33.verse: Jesus asked, “Who are my mother and my brothers [and sisters]?”

34.verse: Then he looked at those sitting around him and said, “·Here are [Look; Behold,] my mother and my brothers [and sisters]!

35.verse: My true brother and sister and mother are those who do ·what God wants [the will of God].”

1.verse: A Story About Planting Seed - Again Jesus began teaching by the lake [the Sea of Galilee]. A great crowd gathered around him, so he sat down in a boat near the shore. All the people stayed on the shore close to the water.

2.verse: Jesus taught them many things, using ·stories [parables; see 3:23]. He said,

3.verse: “Listen! A ·farmer [sower] went out to ·plant [sow] his seed.

4.verse: While he was ·planting [sowing], some seed fell ·by the road [along the path], and the birds came and ate it up.

5.verse: Some seed fell on rocky ground where there wasn’t much dirt. That seed ·grew [sprang up] very fast, because the ground was not deep.

6.verse: But when the sun rose, the plants ·dried up [were scorched and withered] because they did not have deep roots.

7.verse: Some other seed fell among thorny weeds, which grew and choked the good plants. So those plants did not produce ·a crop [grain].

8.verse: Some other seed fell on good ground and began to grow. It got taller and produced ·a crop [grain]. Some plants made thirty times more, some made sixty times more, and some made a hundred times more.”

9.verse: Then Jesus said, ·“Let those with ears use them and listen!” [“Whoever has ears to hear, let him hear.”]

10.verse: Jesus Tells Why He Used Stories - Later, when Jesus was alone, the twelve apostles and others around him asked him about the ·stories [parables; see 3:23].

11.verse: Jesus said, “·You can know [To you has been given] the secret about the kingdom of God. But to ·other people [outsiders] I tell everything by using ·stories [parables]

12.verse: so that: ‘They will look and look, but they will not ·learn [perceive]. They will listen and listen, but they will not understand. ·If they did learn and understand [Otherwise], they ·would [might] ·come back [return] to me and be forgiven [Is. 6:9–10; cf. Is. 43:8; Jer. 5:21; Ezek. 12:2].’”

14.verse: ·The farmer plants God’s message in people [The sower sows the word].

15.verse: Sometimes the ·teaching [word; message] falls ·on the road [along the path]. This is like the people who hear the ·teaching of God [word; message], but Satan quickly comes and takes away the ·teaching [word; message] that was ·planted [sown] in them.

16.verse: Others are like the seed ·planted [sown] on rocky ground. They hear the ·teaching [word; message] and quickly accept it with joy.

17.verse: ·But since they don’t allow the teaching to go deep into their lives [But since they have no root in themselves], they keep it only a short time. When trouble or persecution comes because of the ·teaching they accepted [word; message], they quickly ·give up [fall away; stumble].

18.verse: Others are like the seed planted among the thorny weeds. They hear the ·teaching [word; message],

19.verse: but the worries of this ·life [world; age], the ·temptation [deceitfulness; seduction] of wealth, and ·many other evil desires [desires for other things] ·keep the teaching from growing and producing fruit in their lives [come in and choke the word, making it unfruitful].

20.verse: Others are like the seed ·planted [sown] in the good ground. They hear the ·teaching [word; message] and accept it. Then they grow and produce ·fruit [a crop]—sometimes thirty times more, sometimes sixty times more, and sometimes a hundred times more.”

21.verse: Use What You Have - Then Jesus said to them, “Do you hide a lamp under a ·bowl [basket] or under a bed? No! You put the lamp on a lampstand.

22.verse: [For] Everything that is hidden will be ·made clear [revealed; disclosed] and every ·secret [concealed] thing will be ·made known [brought to light/into the open].

23.verse: ·Let those with ears use them and listen! [“If anyone has ears to hear, let him hear.”]

24.verse: [And he said to them,] “·Think carefully about [Pay attention to] what you hear. ·The way you give to others is the way God will give to you [or The standard you use to judge others will be the standard used for you; With the measure you measure, it will be measured to you], ·but God will give you even more [and even more will be added to you].

25.verse: Those who ·have understanding [have] will be given more. But those who do not ·have understanding [have], even what they have will be taken away from them. [The Greek does not say what they have; but the context suggests spiritual understanding to comprehend the mysteries of the kingdom (v. 11).]

26.verse: Jesus Tells a Story About Seed - Then Jesus said, “The kingdom of God is like someone who ·plants seed in [scatters seed on] the ground.

27.verse: Night and day, whether the person is asleep or awake, the seed still [sprouts and] grows, but the person does not know how it grows.

28.verse: By itself the earth produces grain. First the ·plant [blade; stalk] grows, then the head, and then ·all the [the ripe] grain in the head.

29.verse: When the grain is ready, the farmer cuts it [with a sickle], because this is the harvest time.”

30.verse: A Story About Mustard Seed - Then Jesus said, “How can I show you what the kingdom of God is like? What ·story [parable; see 3:23] can I use to explain it?

32.verse: But when planted, this seed grows and becomes the largest of all garden plants. It produces large branches, and the wild birds can make nests in its shade.”

33.verse: Jesus used many ·stories [parables] like these to teach the crowd God’s ·message [word]—as much as they could ·understand [hear].

34.verse: He always used ·stories [parables] to teach them. But when he and his ·followers [disciples] were alone, Jesus explained everything to them.

35.verse: Jesus Calms a Storm - That evening, Jesus said to ·his followers [them], “Let’s go across the lake.”

36.verse: Leaving the crowd behind, they took him in the boat just as he was [meaning he was already in the boat; 4:1]. There were also other boats with them.

37.verse: A very strong wind came up on the lake. The waves came over the sides and into the boat so that it was ·already full of water [nearly swamped].

38.verse: Jesus was at the ·back of the boat [stern], sleeping on a cushion. ·His followers [They] woke him and said, “Teacher, don’t you care that we are ·drowning [perishing]?”

39.verse: Jesus stood up and ·commanded [reprimanded; rebuked] the wind and said to the ·waves [sea], “·Quiet! [Peace!] Be still!” Then the wind stopped, and it became completely calm. [This parallels God’s subduing of the waters representing chaos in the OT; Ps. 65:7; 89:9; 107:29.]

40.verse: Jesus said to ·his followers [them], “Why are you afraid? Do you still have no faith?”

41.verse: They were ·very afraid [terrified; filled with awe] and asked each other, “Who is this? Even the wind and the ·waves [sea] obey him!”

1.verse: A Man with Demons Inside Him - ·Jesus and his followers [They] went to the other side of the lake to the ·area [land; region] of the ·Gerasene people [Gerasa was southeast of Lake Galilee; the exact location is uncertain].

2.verse: When Jesus got out of the boat, immediately a man with an ·evil [defiling; unclean] spirit came to him from the ·burial caves [tombs; cemetery].

3.verse: This man lived in the ·caves [tombs], and no one could tie him up [any more], not even with a chain.

4.verse: [For] Many times people had used [shackles and] chains to tie the man’s hands and feet, but he always ·broke them off [tore apart the chains and smashed the shackles]. No one was strong enough to ·control [subdue] him.

5.verse: Day and night he would wander around the ·burial caves [tombs] and on the hills, screaming and ·cutting [bruising] himself with stones.

6.verse: While Jesus was still far away, the man saw him, ran to him, and ·fell [bowed] down before him.

7.verse: The man shouted in a loud voice, “·What do you want with me [Let me alone; What business do we have with each other; What to me and to you; see 1:24], Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I ·command [beg; implore; swear to] you in God’s name not to ·torture [torment] me!”

8.verse: He said this because Jesus was saying to him, “You ·evil [defiling; unclean] spirit, come out of the man.”

9.verse: Then Jesus asked him, “What is your name?” He answered, “My name is Legion [a legion was about 5,000 soldiers in the Roman army], because we are many spirits.”

10.verse: He begged Jesus again and again not to send them out of that ·area [land; region].

11.verse: A large herd of pigs was feeding on a hill near there.

12.verse: The demons begged Jesus, “Send us into the pigs; let us go into them.”

13.verse: So Jesus allowed them to do this. The ·evil [defiling; unclean] spirits left the man and went into the pigs. Then the herd of pigs—about two thousand of them—rushed down the ·hill [steep bank; precipice] into the lake and were drowned.

14.verse: The herdsmen ran away and went to the town and to the countryside, telling everyone about this. So people went out to see what had happened.

15.verse: They came to Jesus and saw the man who used to have ·the many evil spirits [the “legion”], sitting, clothed, and in his right mind. And they were frightened.

16.verse: The people who saw this told the others what had happened to the man who had ·the demons living in him [been demon-possessed], and they told about the pigs.

17.verse: Then the people began to beg Jesus to leave their area.

18.verse: As Jesus was getting back into the boat, the man who ·was freed from the demons [had been demon-possessed] begged to go with him.

19.verse: But Jesus would not let him. He said, “Go home to your family and tell them how much the Lord has done for you and how he has had mercy on you.”
